data.title: Beam Rotation
data.statement:
A beam of negligible weight is perfectly horizontal after being hung from a string. The pivot is where the string is attached to the beam, marked by {{^}} character. Boxes have been placed on the beam with their centre of mass being represented by an [[identifier]]. The goal is to determine the [[direction of rotation]] and [[net moment]] acting on the beam.

<<Formulae:>>
• Moment (Nm) = Force (N) * Distance from the pivot ({{^}}) (meters)
• Force (N) = [[mass]] (kg) * 9.81 (acceleration due to Earth's gravity (ms⁻²))

<<Distance:>>
A change in the index of {{1}} corresponds to a distance of {{1}} meter.
Example:
Given [[beam]]: A b ^ B a
b and B are 2 meters from the pivot.
a and A are 4 meters from the pivot.

<<Direction:>>
• A box placed <<LEFT>> of the pivot will create a {{ANTI-CLOCKWISE}} moment.
• A box placed <<RIGHT>> of the pivot will create a {{CLOCKWISE}} moment.

The beam will be {{BALANCED}} if the total clockwise moments are <<EQUAL>> to the total anti-clockwise moments.
The beam will have a [[direction of rotation]] of {{ANTI-CLOCKWISE}} if the total anti-clockwise moments are <<LARGER>> than the total clockwise moments; otherwise, it will be {{CLOCKWISE}}.

<<Net moment acting on the beam:>>
The [[net moment]] acting on the beam is calculated as the absolute difference between the anti-clockwise moments and the clockwise moments.
data.constraints:
1 ≤ Length of [[beam]] ≤ 15
0 ≤ [[n]] ≤ 10
0 < [[mass]] ≤ 1000
There will always be exactly one pivot ({{^}}) in [[beam]].
Each [[identifier]] appears in [[beam]] exactly once.
All [[identifier]]s are unique English letters.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

A beam of negligible weight is perfectly horizontal after being hung from a string. The pivot is where the string is attached to the beam, marked by ^ character. Boxes have been placed on the beam with their centre of mass being represented by an identifier. The goal is to determine the direction of rotation and net moment acting on the beam.

Formulae:
• Moment (Nm) = Force (N) * Distance from the pivot (^) (meters)
• Force (N) = mass (kg) * 9.81 (acceleration due to Earth's gravity (ms⁻²))

Distance:
A change in the index of 1 corresponds to a distance of 1 meter.
Example:
Given beam: A b ^ B a
b and B are 2 meters from the pivot.
a and A are 4 meters from the pivot.

Direction:
• A box placed LEFT of the pivot will create a ANTI-CLOCKWISE moment.
• A box placed RIGHT of the pivot will create a CLOCKWISE moment.

The beam will be BALANCED if the total clockwise moments are EQUAL to the total anti-clockwise moments.
The beam will have a direction of rotation of ANTI-CLOCKWISE if the total anti-clockwise moments are LARGER than the total clockwise moments; otherwise, it will be CLOCKWISE.

Net moment acting on the beam:
The net moment acting on the beam is calculated as the absolute difference between the anti-clockwise moments and the clockwise moments.
Input
Line 1: String beam representing the location of boxes and pivot position (^).
Line 2: Integer n representing the number of boxes placed on the beam.
Next n Lines: Space separated string in the form: identifier mass (float in kg)
Output
Line 1: Direction of rotation: (CLOCKWISE, ANTI-CLOCKWISE or BALANCED).
Line 2: Net moment acting on the beam (rounded to nearest integer) followed by the measurement unit Nm.
Constraints
1 ≤ Length of beam ≤ 15
0 ≤ n ≤ 10
0 < mass ≤ 1000
There will always be exactly one pivot (^) in beam.
Each identifier appears in beam exactly once.
All identifiers are unique English letters.
Example
Input
A b ^ Bea
5
b 10.0
e 1.51
B 10.0
A 10.0
a 10.0
Output
CLOCKWISE
44Nm
